A cow is a domesticated animal that is raised for its meat, milk, and other products.

Cattle are domesticated ungulates, a member of the subfamily Bovinae of the family Bovidae. They are raised as livestock for meat (beef and veal), as dairy animals for milk and other dairy products, and as draft animals (pulling carts, plows and the like).
Beef comes from cows, veal from calves, lamb from sheep, pork from pigs.

Cow meat is the third most widely consumed meat in the world, accounting for about 25% of meat production worldwide, after pork and poultry at 38% and 30% respectively.

Cattle are large grazing animals with two-toed or cloven hooves and a four-chambered stomach.
The cow is a common type of large domesticated ungulate. It is a member of the subfamily Bovinae of the family Bovidae.

The cow is the most common type of large domesticated ungulates. They are a prominent modern member of the subfamily Bovinae, are the most widespread species of the genus Bos, and are most commonly classified collectively as Bos taurus.
A cow is a female that has had at least one calf.
The cow is a mammal that produces milk for its young.
